verses.text: And Satan stood \add up\add* against Israel, and provoked David to number Israel.
And David said to Joab and to the rulers of the people, Go, number Israel from Beer-sheba even to Dan; and bring the number of them to me, that I may know \add it\add*.

And Joab answered, The \sc Lord\sc* make his people an hundred times so many moe as they \add be: but\add*, my lord the king, \add are\add* they not all my lord’s servants? why \add then\add* doth my lord require this \add thing?\add* why will he be a cause of trespass to Israel?
Nevertheless the king’s word prevailed against Joab. Wherefore Joab departed, and went throughout all Israel, and came \add to\add* Jerusalem.

And Joab gave the sum of the number of the people unto David. And all \add they of\add* Israel were a thousand thousand and an hundred thousand men that drew sword: and Judah \add was\add* four hundred threescore and ten thousand men that drew sword.
But Levi and Benjamin counted he not among them: for the king’s word was abominable to Joab.
And God was displeased with this thing; therefore he smote Israel.
And David said unto God, I have sinned greatly, because I have done this thing: but now, I beseech thee, do away the iniquity of thy servant; for I have done very foolishly.
And the \sc Lord\sc* spake unto Gad, David’s seer, saying,
Go and tell David, saying, Thus saith the \sc Lord\sc*, I offer thee three \add things:\add* choose thee one of them, that I may do \add it\add* unto thee.
So Gad came to David, and said unto him, Thus saith the \sc Lord\sc*, Choose thee

either three years’ famine; or three months to be destroyed before thy foes, while that the sword of thine enemies overtaketh \add thee;\add* or else three days the sword of the \sc Lord\sc*, even the pestilence, in the land, and the angel of the \sc Lord\sc* destroying throughout all the coasts of Israel. Now therefore advise thyself what word I shall bring again to him that sent me.
And David said unto Gad, I am in a great strait: let me fall now into the hand of the \sc Lord\sc*; for very great \add are\add* his mercies: but let me not fall into the hand of man.
So the \sc Lord\sc* sent pestilence upon Israel: and there fell of Israel seventy thousand men.

And God sent an angel unto Jerusalem to destroy it: and as \add he\add* was destroying, the \sc Lord\sc* beheld, and he repented him of the evil, and said to the angel that destroyed, \add It is\add* enough, stay now thine hand. And the angel of the \sc Lord\sc* stood by the threshingfloor of Ornan the Jebusite.

And David lift up his eyes, and saw the angel of the \sc Lord\sc* stand between the earth and the heaven, having a drawn sword in his hand stretched out over Jerusalem. Then David and the elders \add of Israel, who were\add* clothed in sackcloth, fell upon their faces.

And David said unto God, \add Is it\add* not I \add that\add* commanded the people to be numbered? even I \add it is\add* that have sinned and done evil indeed; but \add as for\add* these sheep, what have they done? let thine hand, I pray thee, O \sc Lord\sc* my God, be on me, and on my father’s house; but not on thy people, that \add they\add* should be plagued.
Then the angel of the \sc Lord\sc* commanded Gad to say to David, that David should go up, and set up an altar unto the \sc Lord\sc* in the threshingfloor of Ornan the Jebusite.
And David went up at the saying of Gad, which he spake in the name of the \sc Lord\sc*.
And Ornan turned back, and saw the angel; and his four sons with him hid themselves. Now Ornan was threshing wheat.
And as David came to Ornan, Ornan looked and saw David, and went out of the threshingfloor, and bowed himself to David \add with his\add* face to the ground.

Then David said to Ornan, Grant me the place of \add this\add* threshingfloor, that I may build an altar therein unto the \sc Lord\sc*: thou shalt grant it me for the full price: that the plague may be stayed from the people.

And Ornan said unto David, Take \add it\add* to thee, and let my lord the king do \add that\add* which \add is\add* good in his eyes: lo, I give \add thee\add* the oxen \add also\add* for burnt offerings, and the threshing instruments for wood, and the wheat for the meat offering; I give \add it\add* all.

And king David said to Ornan, Nay; but I will verily buy \add it\add* for the full price: for I will not take \add that\add* which \add is\add* thine for the \sc Lord\sc*, nor offer burnt offerings without cost.
So David gave to Ornan for the place six hundred shekels of gold \add by\add* weight.

And David built there an altar unto the \sc Lord\sc*, and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings, and called upon the \sc Lord\sc*; and he answered him from heaven by fire upon the altar of burnt offering.
And the \sc Lord\sc* commanded the angel; and he put up his sword again into the sheath thereof.
At that time when David saw that the \sc Lord\sc* had answered him in the threshingfloor of Ornan the Jebusite, then he sacrificed there.
For the tabernacle of the \sc Lord\sc*, which Moses made in the wilderness, and the altar of the burnt offering, \add were\add* at that season in the high place at Gibeon.
But David could not go before it to inquire of God: for he was afraid because of the sword of the angel of the \sc Lord\sc*.
